question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The Creative Cartography course created a highly engaging and supportive learning environment that encouraged both critical thinking and creative exploration. Professor Triplett structured the course in a way that balanced technical skill-building in map-making with deep conceptual inquiry into spatial narratives and visual storytelling. I particularly appreciated the open-ended nature of the assignments, which allowed me to align course projects with my dissertation interests on historical land use and environmental change.  The class discussions and weekly readings provided a strong theoretical foundation that challenged me to think more deeply about what maps represent—and what they omit. The feedback sessions, especially peer critiques and one-on-one check-ins, were extremely valuable for refining both the design and intent behind my maps.One of the most effective components I would recommend keeping is the scaffolded structure of the final project. It was incredibly helpful to break the process into stages (proposal, moodboard, draft, etc.), which made the final creative deliverable feel achievable and purposeful. I also found the integration of both analog and digital cartographic techniques to be pedagogically rich, and I’d encourage maintaining that blend in future iterations of the course.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I loved learning a little about cartography through our course readings outside of the lab work. The class felt very well - rounded because I was not only engaging with readings and discussions, but also with the mapping program itself. I also appreciate that I was encouraged to think creatively and given plenty of freedom to design my project.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Not only did the instructor teach all the basic skills of navigating the software, he made sure that he would be happy to help you learn any additional skills that might be useful for the topic you chose. The way he can teach the material tailored to each student's level, interest, and type of project was wonderful, and though it was a large class, it still had a depth of one-on-one teaching.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I wish I could take the same course again because I feel like it would be just as stimulating the second time around.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Pro Triplett was consistently engaged and excited to share his knowledge with us, but for us to feel as though our reflections on new material helped grow the subject matter discussion.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was intellectually stimulating because it invited us to rethink maps not just as tools for representation, but as cultural, political, and artistic artifacts. The integration of critical theory with hands-on design work created a unique space to experiment and question—something I haven’t experienced in other courses. The encouragement to situate our own identities and research within our mapping projects made the work personally meaningful and conceptually rich.What made the course especially engaging was the freedom to pursue a self-directed final project. It pushed me to synthesize spatial analysis, historical research, and visual storytelling in new ways. I was able to explore how cartography can represent liminal spaces and historical erasure—central themes in my dissertation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the mechanism behind cameras and how light works to produce images. I learned to use and shoot with a film camera, including the technical and aesthetic aspects of black and white photography. Developed an eye for light, composition and emotional content to drive artistic and documentary storytelling. Learned darkroom techniques such as film processing, printing, burning and dodging and scanning. Discussion of black-and-white photography in seminar setting as well as notable works by photographers in the past and present.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Susie was an excellent teacher, mentor and professional photographer who emphasized not only the technical aspects of film photography but also the aesthetic and emotional component of what made images compelling. She draws from her experiences to teach us the workflow and process of film developing, processing and printing. Susie was always willing to spend time talking about problems we were facing and devoted time for office hours to make herself as available as possible.

response_text: Definitely one of the most interesting and exciting classes I've taken at Duke. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. The specifics of design thinking to execute a concept (e.g. mapping out exactly what a user is doing and what kind of output or feedback they should be getting in return)
2. Learning to see the logic of design as a whole system (like how an input gives an output, and how that links back to the overall functionality). We did a lot of sketching and diagramming to outline these relationships
3. Imagining more experimental/unique interfaces & thinking of unusual/new ways people can interact with a computer, such as touch, sound, motion, even things like environmental changes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: interface report. Cause we always use mobile apps with designed interfaces in our daily lives. Observing and reflecting is a good way to study how to build up a successful interface for a specific purpose.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The self-directed structure of the class let us explore our own interests in-depth by sticking with one project throughout the semester. I liked that we weren’t boxed into one kind of interface or topic & our presentations let each of us dive into interfaces that we were genuinely curious about. The presentation-based format also made it easy to learn from each other and see a wide range. I liked the flexible structure & think it encouraged creativity. We also kept our own "Book of Notice" throughout the semester & it was up to us what we put/how often we updated; this was also a nice way to be creative & see/be inspired by our moodboards.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Every student present every week which keeps everyone engaged, and the professor gives feedback and guidance and help you learn based on what you researched.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: A new perspective to think and analyze the interface that we always use, and add our ideas to a new interface project.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I liked that we got to define our own direction and explore ideas that genuinely interested us. To make the class even more intellectually stimulating, it could be helpful to look at a broader range of real-world experimental interfaces together as a class. While we were encouraged to explore, some of the presentations—both mine and others—started to feel a bit repetitive and leaned heavily toward apps and consumer products. It would’ve been exciting to get more exposure to how different interface concepts are being applied in fields like art, tech, and research. Professor Seaman was also knowledgeable & knew a lot of different interfaces/works/research relevant to our presentation/project topics off the top of his head; it might have been more engaging to learn directly from some examples/insights alongside student presentations.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was stimulating in a way that it makes you discover things yourself, and do what you want to do. It's really what you make of it, if you put in more work you will learn more.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think this class was stimulating because I was able to work on a project that pushed me to step outside of my boundaries.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was not intellectually stimulating. I would propose that students work towards making an actual website at the end of the project instead of making a slideshow presentation as we did not implement any skills of interface design. This class is more accurately described as a discussion class since there was a lack of knowledge being applied. Each week’s class was the same with presentations taking the entire period, so I would get rid of these a commit to having an open discussion about specific principles and techniques each class to add direction.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

However, if you really want to be challenged immensely, this may not be the course for you. Overall though, I really enjoyed it and would recommend it as a new skill that's super cool to learn.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about public policy which was something I hadn't focused on here at Duke.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about what arts policy was, from the history of it to how it relates to my everyday life. I also learned great project-based skills like time management and communication. Furthermore, I learned how to write a policy brief, which is something I didn't know how to do before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical analysis of policies and institutions - i.e. considering how institutions are created and situated, and how this impacts the people attracted to this institution and how that institution is perceived

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was able to build knowledge in U.S. public policy, art and the intersection of both in a very engaging and practical way.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of subtle, overlooked concepts. Creative placemaking, the interplay of public/private/non-profit institutions, and this is the biggest thing: a greater appreciation of arts institutions & events around me. Before this class, I really didn't look to go to museums or art exhibits or dance performances. However, my positive experiences with these aforementioned things have motivated me to go to more events around campus and Durham. I think this is most notable with the performances in Page Auditorium. I will also say this course has helped me network/ reach out when working with my community partner. This was especially relevant when I wanted to include an extra component in the project and I had to gather the resources/data from different teams in the organization and outside.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Understanding of public arts policy decision-making

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about what exactly is arts policy, various cultural institutions and its issues, leadership and value in the arts, cultural equity (audience and access, heritage and repatriation), creative placemaking, and creative economies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We reviewed case studies in arts leadership, visited local cultural organizations, and discussed the challenges facing the arts today. A central component of the course was the extended engagement with a community partner, so we developed our collaborative skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think about art in a different and new context. I also learned professional skills through the service learning aspect of the course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about cultural and arts policies, and how we can observe the phenomenons of these policies in real life. I gained insight on the impacts of cultural and arts policy, and how each action affects the communities around us.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Learned more about all different aspects of art policy
2. Learned how the arts directly spur economic activity
3. How to collaborate professionally in a workplace

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Specifically I learned how to analysis and interpret arts policy in the real world today and apply my leadership knowledge in unique ways to make a difference both in Durham and my local community here at Duke. I learned how to critically engage with peers about arts policy and discuss with them. Lastly, I learned how to work with community partners to ensure long-term success.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

This is very dependent on the people in the class, though. I know there were 6-7 key yappers, but in a class with more shy people or only a few key people speaking, it would be much more anxious/forced.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course is probably the most impactful class I have taken at Duke because I learned and experienced so much. We also went on multiple class excursions that allowed us to understand how the audience interacts with the art institutions, as well as our experience with it. Everything in this course- especially the content- was so meaningful and important for me to learn about.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The biggest stimulating factor were the fieldtrips & the semester long project. They were more dynamic and allowed us to incorporate a lot of skills we personally had. This was most seen in the writing assignments, such as the discussion posts. There was a lot of critical thinking and realization that "oh yeah, this particular institution shows a concept we highlighted in class" or "I did not even realize this institution probably had to mull over their economics & that this affected their policy." I think the final paper was kind of shoved in there at the end, but I much prefer that over any final exam.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to conduct research specifically focused on clothing and design, how in-class student critique is structured, and the fundamentals of painting with watercolor.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I finally picked up watercoloring again after many years. In this class, I learned about different methods to apply water colors (dry on dry, wet on wet, using salt or alcohol on the paper, etc.). I also learned about using undertones for shading.
In terms of costumes, I learned of the new frontiers of costume technology, such as fiber optic lights and thermochromic material, and how they are applied to theater. In a more "ways of thinking," aspect, I was surprised at how the same text can inspire countless variations in different settings, time periods, eras, etc. (and that these can also be seen on the stage, such as the Tempest that took place on a cruise or a women's prison).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have acquired a lot of sketching skills, for instance imagining human heads as eggs and how sketching is very similar with algebra. Oh I also learned how to steam clothes from Hannah. Crucial life skills! I definitely have to work on watercolor painting more in the future.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I honed my drawing skills during the course, particularly in capturing human bodies and motions. The emphasis on drawing loosely to convey movement greatly benefited my figure sketching. Additionally, I delved into watercolor techniques, although my primary focus remained on figure drawing.
The course also provided ample opportunities to refine my concept development skills. I learned to take my understanding of a text and expand it into a comprehensive concept. While the course didn't specifically emphasize the quality and completeness of concepts, I dedicated time to enhance my ability in this area.
Lastly, I cultivated the skill of critiquing my peers' work. I gained insights into their thought processes and the journey leading to their final products. Engaging in in-class critiques provided valuable exposure to such situations and significantly contributed to my familiarity with the process.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Fabric, watercolor, rough sketch of costume

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course was small and the instructor encouraged everyone to contribute and share their ideas. Teaching us to give positive and helpful critiques from the start made me feel less judged when presenting my work and able to help others constructively. Hands on rendering activities and discussions were well balanced. There was an overall very encouraging, forgiving, and positive learning environment which I think helped me engage a lot more than I would in a bigger class or with a different instructor. One on one midterm meetings helped me see my progress. The professor was very understanding of our needs and abilities and adjusted deadlines/expectations to fit all students. I think this made everyone work harder and reach their own potential.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course was very focused on critique and repeated iterations of a project, which was impactful because it challenged me to improve my designs each time rather than being satisfied with the first rendition. I also found the in-class practice for sketching and use of artistic media to be helpful, as I was not at all familiar with watercolor and didn't have any formal knowledge of figure drawing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

A simple 3 minute sketch everyday to keep track of my mood each day is something that I would keep for future years. I loved that way of keeping traces of my daily life. It's meditative as well.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The class serves as an introduction to the field of costume design, making it accessible without requiring any prior knowledge. Currently, the course is primarily hands-on, emphasizing extensive sketching and drawing practice. Although our drawing abilities are not directly evaluated, they play a significant role in the course. If there's a prerequisite for this class, it would be a passion for drawing or, at the very least, a willingness to engage in frequent drawing practice.Structured akin to a standard art course, regular critiques and presentations are integral components, occurring nearly every week. Beyond providing an overview of costume design, the course offers an immersive art school experience for those inclined toward design. Hannah, the instructor, excels in communication and adeptly facilitates meaningful discussions, enhancing the overall experience of this discussion-intensive class.I wish the class is offered twice a week instead of once.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor, Professor Torry Bend, offered each student individualized feedback on our design process and developed product. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course is inspirational and stimulating, especially for students wanting to go further in the arts field. Throughout the course, I developed a further understanding of how to take a holistic approach toward scene design in theatrical productions, how to work collaboratively with other artists, and how to be assertive about my artistic choice while being open to advice and opinions. It is a great course for emerging artists; however, the workload is heavy, with many hands-on crafting assignments. It is a difficult but intellectually stimulating course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The process of designing lights for a theatrical production, a greater appreciation for the role that lighting plays in everyday life, and the specific software, jargon, and methodologies used by theatrical lighting designers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the theory of how to light theater and dance performances, how to use software to implement this theory, and how to physically hang and focus lights.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Developing a plan to augment a theatrical performance using lighting design
- Using lighting design software used in industry. Specifically how to patch, program, and change lighting units using the EOS software.
- Learned about the different types of theater lights, when to use them, and their positions on the stage. Talked about the effects that different types of intensity, movement, and light color can have on a performance's mood and atmosphere.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned the technical aspects that go into a lighting design such as color, intensity and position.
2. I learned how to hang lights within a theater.
3. I learned how to successfully use eos software to program the lights in a theater.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed understanding of common terminology in lighting design and technical theater as well as an understanding of the general design and application process of light in a theatrical production. The course has a nice balance of the amount of hand-on experience and lecture, providing me equal opportunities to learn the terminology of the field and to develop a better sense of how the process really looks like. I have also got the opportunity to see the creative process of professionals working in the field of light design as well as the professional standard for associated paperwork in the industry.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I feel much more competent with all the equipment and theory than I did at the beginning of the class. Learned about moving lights as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of interesting facts about breast cancer, such as differing opinions on Breast Cancer Awareness Month and about Audre Lorde's "The Cancer Journals." I learned how breast cancer could be tied together with feminism, and the concept of phenomenology.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
How women are objectified in society 
How breast cancer can be a lens to examine women's border role in society 
How to analyze performance art

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learning critique and analyze pieces of art was insightful. I also learned about the medical gaze and glance which I never even knew existed. I have taken a small seminar like this in some time and it was nice to hear at times opposing views and expose myself to thoughts that aren’t similar to mine.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the waves of feminism, about the intersection of the medical gaze and the male gaze, and about the ways that gender, class, race, sexuality and more interact to shape women’s experiences with breast cancer and its associated treatment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about breast cancer and how it is represented in various forms of art, such as paintings, photographs, journals, essays, poems, and other forms of writing. Beyond the topic, I was able to work on my writing skills, as we had multiple informal writings and formal writings throughout the semester, with ample feedback from Professor Lamm, so I could work on every piece of writing for the next one. I also improved my reading skills, pulling out the important parts of a piece and pulling out evidence to support it, and also my speaking skills as we did a lot of discussions in class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) how to better analyze pieces of literature and artwork surrounding various themes of breast cancer, feminism, and intersectionality
2) the importance of representation and the various ways in which people's identities have historically been ignored, mocked, or silenced
3) a better understanding of the ways in which art and storytelling intersect and the way artists can infuse their works with important messages.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

I also loved the trip to the Nasher as it was another way to explore the themes and goals of the course reflected by an everyday example. I also liked that the papers were open-ended and allowed for the writer to reflect on their own experiences and pick the works we examined in class that most resonated with them. I would keep all of these elements for future years.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

You are allowed to "re-use" content from your informal writings to help guide your formal writings, in fact they are set up to prepare you for the formal writing. So really not too bad at all in terms of workload. Readings, on average, take no more than 3 hours per week.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how to create meaning in video, from both the perspective of the maker and the viewer. I also learned about the ways that video can be used to convey a political message as well as new ways of thinking about what is meaningful and how to create meaning through my video work.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout this course, I was able to expand my way of thinking on many topics that I once thought I knew everything about. I'm amazed by how Professor Jenny Lion was able to take seemingly widespread concepts and dig deeply into what they meant to our society, so much so that we were able to produce creative video art through examining the contexts of everything we discussed within the course. In Video Art and Politics, I developed a deeper understanding of how moving images can function as both aesthetic expression and political intervention. The course expanded my critical lens as a media maker and viewer. Three specific things I learned are:- The Power of Visual Rhetoric – I gained insight into how visual language, framing, and editing choices can shape political meaning and influence audiences emotionally and intellectually. This helped me reflect more intentionally on my own creative decisions and the messages they convey.- Expanded Definitions of Activism and Art – I learned how artists and filmmakers use nontraditional forms, such as video installations, essay films, and acts of tactical media, as political tools. These works challenged me to rethink the boundaries of what counts as political art and to appreciate the role of experimentation in social critique.- Process as Political Practice – Through the final project and class discussions, I understood how the process of making video art (including collaboration, research, and engagement with communities) can itself be a political act. This insight will continue to shape how I approach media production and storytelling in socially engaged contexts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Jenny very much prompted open discussion and wanted us to really critique each other's work properly, not just saying what we liked about the piece. But asking the person whose work it was really what do they need to know, what will help them? I feel like the the first artists using video in the 70s that she showed us were very intriguing and I really enjoyed being exposed to them. Also, Jenny co-ordinated artists to come speak to our class like Wendy Clarke who did The Love Tapes. Jenny said this class is basically about how to change the world - and I really felt like I learnt a lot about activism and how to use my skills in video for things I care about and to help others.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The overall learning environment of Video Art and Politics was deeply engaging and thoughtfully designed to support both creative exploration and critical thinking. The instructor fostered a space that encouraged experimentation, open dialogue, and personal connection to the material, which was crucial for a course dealing with both art and sociopolitical issues.
One of the most impactful components was the balance between theory and practice—readings and screenings provided historical and conceptual context, while creative assignments allowed us to respond artistically. This dual approach helped me internalize complex ideas through hands-on application. I also appreciated the peer feedback sessions and in-class critiques, which created a collaborative and supportive environment. Hearing from others enriched my perspective and gave me practical suggestions to refine my work.For future years, I’d definitely keep the final project format that allowed us to define our own intervention and work across mediums. It encouraged risk-taking and personal investment, making the course feel both rigorous and meaningful.

Weekly screenings and readings sparked deep conversations that often stayed with me long after class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was very helpful in developing technical skills related to filmmaking, editing, film processing, and shooting. Working in the darkroom was a very informative hands-on experience, as was using the Steenbeck manual editing table to splice and cut together films physically. In addition to the Steenbeck editing techniques, we were taught how to use Adobe Lightroom to edit our films digitally. I also got comfortable using the Bolex camera while making films for the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a fun intro level course to 16mm film! If you want time to do some hands on art, this is the place. Shooting and developing can be a little stressful, but Madison was always very responsive and helpful when reached out to. Make sure you take notes in class to prepare for shooting, and start your projects far before they are due.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Please take this course! Madison is a wonderful instructor who will introduce you to the joys and intricacies of analog filmmaking. Although analog can be frustrating at times, this course allows you to experience both the excitement of getting it right (film turning out as intended) and the mistakes that are inherent to 16mm filmmaking, without the stress of having to be the perfect filmmaker. Instead, grace is given for all students to learn the medium and experiment with their own creative impulses.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I got a lot better at my craft. Getting to practice it for a whole semester, following my own methodology, is amazing and such a privilege!I learned how to present my progress. Progress comes in all forms, and sometimes it isn't as tangible or immediately noticeable so it must be communicated verbally instead. But this communication, whether it is in the form of a Powerpoint or spoken word, is important so that the class can give good feedback and my involvement is still evident.I learned how to plan a semester-long project from start to finish. I've never done something like this before because the longest project I've ever completed was about half a semester long, with pre-made guidelines. Writing my own syllabus was a new exercise for me. I also learned how to set goals.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think the skill I most developed over the course of this semester was self-discipline. In creating my short film, I really had to organize my time effectively and motivate myself to keep on track, and I felt like this course helped us structure the development of this skill well. I also learned a lot about the process of production and all the little administrative tasks that go into making a film. Finally, I got better at presenting unfinished works in front of people. Normally, in the past, I would only ever show finished works. However, to receive valuable feedback, I have realized that showing progress to people along the way is really important.

-System-thinking on how to manipulate sound to give a desired effect
-Punctuation, concrete vs. abstract, time manipulation, and other techniques for sound design
-Collaboration on final project involving live and digital instruments and sounds

sound software

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The Creative Cartography course created a highly engaging and supportive learning environment that encouraged both critical thinking and creative exploration. Professor Triplett structured the course in a way that balanced technical skill-building in map-making with deep conceptual inquiry into spatial narratives and visual storytelling. I particularly appreciated the open-ended nature of the assignments, which allowed me to align course projects with my dissertation interests on historical land use and environmental change.  The class discussions and weekly readings provided a strong theoretical foundation that challenged me to think more deeply about what maps represent—and what they omit. The feedback sessions, especially peer critiques and one-on-one check-ins, were extremely valuable for refining both the design and intent behind my maps.One of the most effective components I would recommend keeping is the scaffolded structure of the final project. It was incredibly helpful to break the process into stages (proposal, moodboard, draft, etc.), which made the final creative deliverable feel achievable and purposeful. I also found the integration of both analog and digital cartographic techniques to be pedagogically rich, and I’d encourage maintaining that blend in future iterations of the course.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I loved learning a little about cartography through our course readings outside of the lab work. The class felt very well - rounded because I was not only engaging with readings and discussions, but also with the mapping program itself. I also appreciate that I was encouraged to think creatively and given plenty of freedom to design my project.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Not only did the instructor teach all the basic skills of navigating the software, he made sure that he would be happy to help you learn any additional skills that might be useful for the topic you chose. The way he can teach the material tailored to each student's level, interest, and type of project was wonderful, and though it was a large class, it still had a depth of one-on-one teaching.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I wish I could take the same course again because I feel like it would be just as stimulating the second time around.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was intellectually stimulating because it invited us to rethink maps not just as tools for representation, but as cultural, political, and artistic artifacts. The integration of critical theory with hands-on design work created a unique space to experiment and question—something I haven’t experienced in other courses. The encouragement to situate our own identities and research within our mapping projects made the work personally meaningful and conceptually rich.What made the course especially engaging was the freedom to pursue a self-directed final project. It pushed me to synthesize spatial analysis, historical research, and visual storytelling in new ways. I was able to explore how cartography can represent liminal spaces and historical erasure—central themes in my dissertation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Ways of understanding how breast cancer is represented
Understanding a feminist school of thought and how it's changed over the years
Ability to analyze texts and photos

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze texts, how to write with a strong argument, how to understand art and multi-media

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of interesting facts about breast cancer, such as differing opinions on Breast Cancer Awareness Month and about Audre Lorde's "The Cancer Journals." I learned how breast cancer could be tied together with feminism, and the concept of phenomenology.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
How women are objectified in society 
How breast cancer can be a lens to examine women's border role in society 
How to analyze performance art

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learning critique and analyze pieces of art was insightful. I also learned about the medical gaze and glance which I never even knew existed. I have taken a small seminar like this in some time and it was nice to hear at times opposing views and expose myself to thoughts that aren’t similar to mine.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the waves of feminism, about the intersection of the medical gaze and the male gaze, and about the ways that gender, class, race, sexuality and more interact to shape women’s experiences with breast cancer and its associated treatment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about breast cancer and how it is represented in various forms of art, such as paintings, photographs, journals, essays, poems, and other forms of writing. Beyond the topic, I was able to work on my writing skills, as we had multiple informal writings and formal writings throughout the semester, with ample feedback from Professor Lamm, so I could work on every piece of writing for the next one. I also improved my reading skills, pulling out the important parts of a piece and pulling out evidence to support it, and also my speaking skills as we did a lot of discussions in class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) how to better analyze pieces of literature and artwork surrounding various themes of breast cancer, feminism, and intersectionality
2) the importance of representation and the various ways in which people's identities have historically been ignored, mocked, or silenced
3) a better understanding of the ways in which art and storytelling intersect and the way artists can infuse their works with important messages.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to articulate my thoughts to the group in a more organized and clear way, and the virtue of taking notes on paper. I also learned how to write shorter essays and develop that into a bigger, longer, and more elaborated version.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to analyze complex academics texts, identify the key ideas and synthesize my knowlege with topics already discussed in class

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Feminist insights about breast cancer
- How breast cancer unveils broader race and gender hierarchies
- Different artistic and literary representations of breast cancer

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Representing breast cancer was a very insightful class. I learned to think about other factors that affect patient care and disease incidence. I was able to better my writing skills with the three informal assignments and the three formal papers as well as the reflection.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of subtle, overlooked concepts. Creative placemaking, the interplay of public/private/non-profit institutions, and this is the biggest thing: a greater appreciation of arts institutions & events around me. Before this class, I really didn't look to go to museums or art exhibits or dance performances. However, my positive experiences with these aforementioned things have motivated me to go to more events around campus and Durham. I think this is most notable with the performances in Page Auditorium. I will also say this course has helped me network/ reach out when working with my community partner. This was especially relevant when I wanted to include an extra component in the project and I had to gather the resources/data from different teams in the organization and outside.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to conduct research specifically focused on clothing and design, how in-class student critique is structured, and the fundamentals of painting with watercolor.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I finally picked up watercoloring again after many years. In this class, I learned about different methods to apply water colors (dry on dry, wet on wet, using salt or alcohol on the paper, etc.). I also learned about using undertones for shading.
In terms of costumes, I learned of the new frontiers of costume technology, such as fiber optic lights and thermochromic material, and how they are applied to theater. In a more "ways of thinking," aspect, I was surprised at how the same text can inspire countless variations in different settings, time periods, eras, etc. (and that these can also be seen on the stage, such as the Tempest that took place on a cruise or a women's prison).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have acquired a lot of sketching skills, for instance imagining human heads as eggs and how sketching is very similar with algebra. Oh I also learned how to steam clothes from Hannah. Crucial life skills! I definitely have to work on watercolor painting more in the future.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I honed my drawing skills during the course, particularly in capturing human bodies and motions. The emphasis on drawing loosely to convey movement greatly benefited my figure sketching. Additionally, I delved into watercolor techniques, although my primary focus remained on figure drawing.
The course also provided ample opportunities to refine my concept development skills. I learned to take my understanding of a text and expand it into a comprehensive concept. While the course didn't specifically emphasize the quality and completeness of concepts, I dedicated time to enhance my ability in this area.
Lastly, I cultivated the skill of critiquing my peers' work. I gained insights into their thought processes and the journey leading to their final products. Engaging in in-class critiques provided valuable exposure to such situations and significantly contributed to my familiarity with the process.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Fabric, watercolor, rough sketch of costume

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course was small and the instructor encouraged everyone to contribute and share their ideas. Teaching us to give positive and helpful critiques from the start made me feel less judged when presenting my work and able to help others constructively. Hands on rendering activities and discussions were well balanced. There was an overall very encouraging, forgiving, and positive learning environment which I think helped me engage a lot more than I would in a bigger class or with a different instructor. One on one midterm meetings helped me see my progress. The professor was very understanding of our needs and abilities and adjusted deadlines/expectations to fit all students. I think this made everyone work harder and reach their own potential.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course was very focused on critique and repeated iterations of a project, which was impactful because it challenged me to improve my designs each time rather than being satisfied with the first rendition. I also found the in-class practice for sketching and use of artistic media to be helpful, as I was not at all familiar with watercolor and didn't have any formal knowledge of figure drawing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the class critiques were a big help. As mentioned above, everyone brought their own backgrounds and perspectives/interpretations of each piece, and that really opened up my eyes to how I could make my own designs more accessible/ open to general audiences.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The critique sure helped me a lot. I enjoyed being affirmed (haha of course) by someone who is more authoritative than me in the field, and also my peers. And they offered gentle suggestions that helped me a lot.
A simple 3 minute sketch everyday to keep track of my mood each day is something that I would keep for future years. I loved that way of keeping traces of my daily life. It's meditative as well.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The class serves as an introduction to the field of costume design, making it accessible without requiring any prior knowledge. Currently, the course is primarily hands-on, emphasizing extensive sketching and drawing practice. Although our drawing abilities are not directly evaluated, they play a significant role in the course. If there's a prerequisite for this class, it would be a passion for drawing or, at the very least, a willingness to engage in frequent drawing practice.Structured akin to a standard art course, regular critiques and presentations are integral components, occurring nearly every week. Beyond providing an overview of costume design, the course offers an immersive art school experience for those inclined toward design. Hannah, the instructor, excels in communication and adeptly facilitates meaningful discussions, enhancing the overall experience of this discussion-intensive class.I wish the class is offered twice a week instead of once.

response_text: I learned various design principles as they apply to costuming, drawing and watercolor techniques when rendering the human figure, practical considerations when designing for a show (budget, swatching, sourcing), and script analysis.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course is inspirational and stimulating, especially for students wanting to go further in the arts field. It is a great course for emerging artists; however, the workload is heavy, with many hands-on crafting assignments. It is a difficult but intellectually stimulating course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The process of designing lights for a theatrical production, a greater appreciation for the role that lighting plays in everyday life, and the specific software, jargon, and methodologies used by theatrical lighting designers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the theory of how to light theater and dance performances, how to use software to implement this theory, and how to physically hang and focus lights.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Developing a plan to augment a theatrical performance using lighting design
- Using lighting design software used in industry. Specifically how to patch, program, and change lighting units using the EOS software.
- Learned about the different types of theater lights, when to use them, and their positions on the stage. Talked about the effects that different types of intensity, movement, and light color can have on a performance's mood and atmosphere.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned the technical aspects that go into a lighting design such as color, intensity and position.
2. I learned how to hang lights within a theater.
3. I learned how to successfully use eos software to program the lights in a theater.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed understanding of common terminology in lighting design and technical theater as well as an understanding of the general design and application process of light in a theatrical production. The course has a nice balance of the amount of hand-on experience and lecture, providing me equal opportunities to learn the terminology of the field and to develop a better sense of how the process really looks like. I have also got the opportunity to see the creative process of professionals working in the field of light design as well as the professional standard for associated paperwork in the industry.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to use an ETC lighting console, how to hang and focus lights, and learned about the qualities and functions of light and practiced making lighting designs based on all this. I feel much more competent with all the equipment and theory than I did at the beginning of the class. Learned about moving lights as well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text: There was a great blend of theory and practice. I would keep the in-class lab time and I would keep the projects where we make a lighting design for a mood, a phrase, and some songs. Those projects were all really fun and informative.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I really liked the blend of lighting theory and practice, and the professor was always super knowledgeable and willing to answer questions even if they were a bit beyond the scope of the class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I thought that the course was intellectually stimulating. As I mentioned earlier, having more opportunities to work on real projects and performances instead of just projects for the class would have helped me explore lighting design at a higher level.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The professor was very warm, open and welcoming. He accepted all different types of people and listened to everyone's different points of view.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The prompt for each assignment is designed to be intellectually stimulating since it connects lighting with emotions and experience. The topics, such as to express a certain emotion with one light design, are interesting and inspiring since it requires me to reflect on my emotional experience and to express it in a way that is understandable by others. However, the assignments are less open to students with a different perspective and aesthetic language than the majority of the student body since the assignments are graded based on how well it is perceived in the most general and common perspective.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: All of the light lab projects were intellectually stimulating and generally awesome.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Practice using the light board as much as possible - the software is the most difficult part to master since you kind of have to be in the theater to use it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a perfect introduction to the world of lighting design. I think that it is a good mix of the theory and applications of lighting design in theater. The class is not too much work, but provides you with opportunities to do a lot of extra experimentation on the projects if you are really interested in lighting design.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this class! It is a very hands-on class where you will learn a lot about the different aspects of what goes on behind the scenes in the theater.  Professor is great and so were other students in my class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course does not require an artistic background; instead, it challenges all students to think artistically and be inspired in an artistic way. However, since light design does not require any specific skills, it is open to students with all levels and backgrounds. It is at a balance of artistic training and technical training, exposing students to both theatrical design and technology. The course functions well as an introduction into theatrical technology in general with lots of hand-on opportunities.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Bill and the class are both great! You need no experience to take the class, and also you can make your projects as advanced as you want depending on your level and goals. For example, we had the option of whether to use moving lights or not.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Spatialization of sound and storytelling for sound; orientation to an analog mixer, basic physics of sound, QLab, Reaper, dynamics, sound system plotting for live performance.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
